qas.question: How many estimated active faults does Houston have?
What is the total length of the Houston faults?
Which of the geologic faults run through the center of Houston?
What geological feature has been removed underground to cause sinking in areas of southeast Houston?
What is a slow smooth rate of movement of faults called?
How many estimated unactive faults does Houston have?
What is the total width of the Houston faults?
Which of the geologic faults run through the center of Texas?
What geological feature has been placed underground to cause sinking in areas of southeast Houston?
What is a fast smooth rate of movement of faults called?

context: The Houston area has over 150 active faults (estimated to be <a0_0><b5_0>300<b5_0/><a0_0/> active faults) with an aggregate length of up to <a1_0><b6_0>310 miles<b6_0/><a1_0/> (500 km), including the <a2_0><b7_0>Long Point–Eureka<b7_0/> Heights<a2_0/> fault system which runs through the center of the city. There have been no significant historically recorded earthquakes in Houston, but researchers do not discount the possibility of such quakes having occurred in the deeper past, nor occurring in the future. Land in some areas southeast of Houston is sinking because <a3_0><b8_0>water<b8_0/><a3_0/> has been pumped out of the ground for many years. It may be associated with slip along the faults; however, the slippage is slow and not considered an earthquake, where stationary faults must slip suddenly enough to create seismic waves. These faults also tend to move at a smooth rate in what is termed "<a4_0><b9_0>fault creep<b9_0/><a4_0/>", which further reduces the risk of an earthquake.
